Summary: The proposal aims to develop a hybrid model combining spiking neural networks (SNNs) and a biologically inspired gating mechanism to bridge the gap between computational models of attention and cognitive neuroscience. It includes validation via synthetic tasks, neural data alignment, clinical applications, and scalability benchmarking.
Strengths: Clear and well-articulated problem statement highlighting gaps in existing models.
Ambitious hypothesis integrating SNNs and thalamocortical interactions.
Detailed and methodical validation plan, including synthetic tasks, neural data alignment, and clinical applications.
Strong alignment with cognitive neuroscience and potential clinical relevance (e.g., ADHD).
Weaknesses: Feasibility of integrating SNNs with large-scale convolutional backbones is not thoroughly discussed.
Potential technical challenges in real-time adaptation and scalability are understated.
Limited discussion on interpretability challenges when correlating model outputs with fMRI/EEG data.
Ablation studies, while planned, lack detail on how they will isolate specific mechanisms.
Questions: How will the proposed hybrid architecture handle the computational inefficiency of SNNs in large-scale tasks?
What specific measures will be taken to ensure the interpretability of model outputs when aligned with fMRI/EEG data?
Are there fallback plans if the integration of SNNs with convolutional backbones proves infeasible?
Limitations: Scalability of SNNs in hybrid architectures remains unproven for large-scale tasks.
Interpretability of model outputs in relation to neural data may be challenging.
Potential overfitting when aligning model predictions with limited fMRI/EEG datasets.
